pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:0.5: 5. The training rule on receiving robe-cloth
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.2: At that time the nun Uppalavaṇṇā was staying at Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.3: One morning she robed up, took her bowl and robe, and entered Sāvatthī to collect almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.4: When she had finished her almsround and had eaten her meal, she went to spend the day in the Blind Men’s Grove,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.5: where she sat down at the foot of a tree.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.6: Just then some bandits, who had stolen a cow and slaughtered it, were taking the meat to the Blind Men’s Grove.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.7: The head bandit saw Uppalavaṇṇā sitting at the foot of that tree.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.9: “If my sons and brothers see this nun, they’ll harass her,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.10: and he took a different path.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.11: Soon afterwards, when the meat was cooked, he took some of the best meat, tied it up in a palm-leaf packet, hung it from a tree not far from Uppalavaṇṇā, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.12: “Whatever acetic or brahmin sees this gift, please take it.” And he left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.13: Uppalavaṇṇā had just emerged from stillness, and so she heard the head bandit making that statement.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.14: She took the meat and returned to her dwelling place.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.15: When the night was over, she prepared the meat and made it into a bundle with her upper robe. She then rose into the air and appeared in the Bamboo Grove.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.1: When she arrived the Master had already entered a village to collect almsfood,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.2: but Venerable Udāyī had been left behind to look after the monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.5: “He has entered a village to collect almsfood.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.6: “Venerable, please give this meat to the Master.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.7: “You’ll please the Master with that meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.8: If you give me your sarong, you’ll please me too.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.9: “It’s hard for women to get requisites, and this is one of my five robes. I don’t have any other.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.11: “Sister, just as a man giving an elephant might decorate its girth,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.12: so you giving meat to the Master should decorate me with your sarong.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.13: Being pressured by Udāyī, Uppalavaṇṇā gave him her sarong and then returned to her dwelling place.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.14: The nuns who received Uppalavaṇṇā’s bowl and robe asked her,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.16: And she told them what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.17: The nuns complained and criticized Udāyī,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.18: “How can Venerable Udāyī receive a robe from a nun? It’s hard for women to get requisites.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.20: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.21: “How can Venerable Udāyī receive a robe from a nun?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.22: after rebuking him in many ways, they told the Master. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.23: “Is it true, Udāyī, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.27: “Foolish man, a man and a woman who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s right and what’s wrong.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.28: And still you received a robe from the hand of an unrelated nun.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.29: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.30: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.31: ‘If a monk receives a robe-cloth from the hand of an unrelated nun, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.32: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.1: Then, being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not receive robe-cloth from nuns even in exchange.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.2: The nuns complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.3: “How can they not receive robe-cloth from us in exchange?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.4: The monks heard the criticism of those nuns
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.6: Soon afterwards the Master gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.7: “Monks, if it is part of an exchange, I allow you to receive things from five sources: from monks, from nuns, from trainee nuns, from novice monks, and from novice nuns.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.9: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.10: ‘If a monk receives a robe-cloth from the hand of an unrelated nun, unless it is an exchange, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.6: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back seven generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.8: she has been given the full ordination by both Sanghas.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.10: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be transferred.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.13: If he accepts, then the effort constitutes wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.14: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.15: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.16: “And, monks, it should be relinquished in this way.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.17: To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1, paragraphs 13–17](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1#13), with appropriate substitutions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.18: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth which I received from the hand of an unrelated nun is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.19: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.22: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.1: If she is unrelated and he perceives her as unrelated, and he receives robe-cloth from her, unless it is an exchange, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.2: If she is unrelated, but he is unsure if she is, and he receives robe-cloth from her, unless it is an exchange, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.3: If she is unrelated, but he perceives her as related, and he receives robe-cloth from her, unless it is an exchange, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.4: If he receives robe-cloth from the hand of a nun who is fully ordained only on one side, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.5: If she is related, but he perceives her as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.6: If she is related, but he is unsure if she is, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.7: If she is related and he perceives her as related, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.3: if much is exchanged with little or little is exchanged with much;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.4: if he takes it on trust;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.6: if he receives any requisite apart from robe-cloth;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.7: if it is a trainee nun;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.8: if it is a novice nun;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.10: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.11: The fifth rule, the training rule on receiving robe-cloth, is finished.
